data.text: Wide Tyres for a World Tour by Bicycle

What tyres would you recommend for a world tour bike? Looking to go off-road a good amount, but long stretches of tar are unavoidable. Likely going for 26", and would prefer wider tyres so I can skip the suspension.

I can only speak from our experience where we‚Äôve ended up about 80% of tarmac and our perfect tyres are 40mm Mondials on our Disc Truckers. They wear well, roll really sweetly on a sealed road but have good confidence on a loose surface. Also, as a folding tyre, easy enough to carry a spare if you have the weight capacity.
data.author: Mark Litherland

data.text: I used continental travel contact last time, smooth centre strip for the tarmac, knobbly side tread that helps a bit on the rough stuff, good puncture resistance as well, bit of a pain to get off if the worst happens though
data.author: Keith Warner

data.text: Surly Extraterrestrial 26"x2,5" offer a nice cushion of fat air, enough fast rolling tread. I find them not as longlasting as the Marathon Mondials, nevertheless prefer their comfort!
data.author: Supp Suppinger

data.text: These look great! I was hoping to find something wider. Any idea how long they'd last? The other wide-ish 26" I've found is continental cross king which my wheel builder suggested, but I like the Surly's you've mentioned.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: The continentals x-kings are good if you get the ‚Äúprotection‚Äù series. Would probably be on a very short list of tires I would have confidence in for off-road touring in remote areas. Have used them for bike packing and xc racing with no trouble.
data.author: Jarod Cassada

data.text: Hmm, that's interesting you rate them so high. Cause I was suggested them by a top-end wheel builder here in London. Might just accept the lower width. How well do they handle things like rocks and mud?
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: The Surlys might last several thousands of km's. I did some very heavy touring with them. After a few 1000s of kms I noticed the rear tyre being noticable more worn than the front tyre. Even when the green inner rubber was visible, they still stood strong. No single puncture. Wear is more noticable than on the Mondials. But just my observation, not science ;-) The Contis seem to have "longer", bigger tread.
data.author: Supp Suppinger

data.text: Not great for rocks. The harder compound can result in tread knobs snapping off. However, I have run these with missing knobs to almost bald until sealant weeped from the sidewalls without a flat.
data.author: Jarod Cassada

data.text:
I know the Schwalbe Marathon Plus Tour HS 440 are super durable, seem to have really go smooth tread for black top with some grip on the sides when going off road. I think that is what I would be using, personally... https://www.schwalbetires.com/bike_tires/road_tires/marathon_plus_tour
Marathon Plus Tour Road Bike Tire - HS 404 | Schwalbe Tires
schwalbetires.com
data.author: Sam Carleton

data.text: they only seem to go up to 26x2", and I'd prefer wider. I have 2" on my gravel bike and I feel I need more to for the rougher terrain. Otherwise I agree heard great things about these.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: That is a bummer! I did own a set of the Schwalbe Marathon Plus HS 440, one thing I did notice was they are heavy and slow. So... I would imagine a wider version of the Tour might start to get too heavy. My guess is the Tour are really designed for pavement touring (aka higher risk of puncture from all sort of things on the pavement) with light off-road.
data.author: Sam Carleton

data.text: It depends on the terrain. I used to ride in Iceland with a slick profile on my mountibkes and have a spare tyre with me for the worst parts so I could change. It can be changed in about 10 minutes time and you have always a spare tyre in case a tyre is not good anymore. And I always had two spare inner tyres with me. Do not forget a very good pump, because if you cannot pump a flat tyre you can have a serious problem.
data.author: Rutger van den Hoofdakker

data.text: Only one option for a world tour Schwable Marathon nothing beats them. Bulletproof!!!
data.author: Don Gregoire

data.text: I like 2.3‚Äù treads for long tours and off-roading. Lots of options from Maxxis etc.
data.author: Michael Manning

data.text: I use 2" Schwalbe Marathon E plus tires, super heavy, but I just went 3,000 km without a flat. I wouldn't recommend them, though, for real off-road riding. You'll need decent lugs for that and I would go 2.3" as that is as big as I can manage on my bike. Maybe the Marathon plus tour. I haven't used them, though. I have used many sets of Continental travel contact tires. They are 1.75" so I don't think they're big enough for real off-road riding. The side lugs are helpful in loose gravel. Good flat patch for the road.
data.author: Marshall Bradbury

data.text: There is only one option: Schwalbe Marathon Mundial evo
data.author: Stefan la Grand

data.text: too narrow and road-oriented for me.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: I rode the pamir Highway including the Wakhan valley in Tadzikistan on them‚Ä¶fully loaded‚Ä¶..no punctures üëå
data.author: Stefan la Grand

data.text: that's tar though isn't it? I also had zero punctures on my 2500km ride on half gravel half tar this past month. On rene hersch tyres.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: the Mondial is available up to at least 2.15", maybe even 2.3". They are designed for all sorts of roads and tracks, not just sealed tarmac.
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: tar?? Haha no way‚Ä¶it is gravel and holes with some tar in between themüôÑ
data.author: Stefan la Grand

data.text: oh cool. I'm sorry, was asking cause wasn't sure. How rough is the gravel? Heard of it off course and would love to go there one day. It goes through stunning places, and I'm going to Pakistan early next year(before this trip) e where I won't be far from parts of it.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: tarmac is sometimes ok..the gravel is very rough!
data.author: Stefan la Grand

data.text: did you feel like you would have benefited from wider tyres? Sounds like yes?
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: not really. I rode 42 mm wide tires and it was mostly fine. Plus some speed on tarmac‚Ä¶
data.author: Stefan la Grand

data.text: Marathons are so heavy, I'm not a fan. There's a wide range of tires to choose from.... Traveling international you're better with 26" rather than 700. I agree with more volume.... Taller and fatter tire, I like a tire with a wide Ridgeline down the center for less resistance on the road and some traction on the shoulders...... Or, nearly slick.
data.author: Samuel Lea

data.text: Samuel Lea not all Marathons are the same. It is the Marathon Plus that are the really heavy tyres. For a better world touring tyre get the Marathon Mondial. And slick tyres or ridgeline tyres leave you very vulnerable to gravel road wash-outs in turns. VERY hazardous should the front tyre slide out. Ask me why I know.
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: agree, I've used schwalbe land cruisers and hurricanes. The low rolling resistance is great on road but when the gravel gets deep steering control is lost :( Running vitoria terranos now, cornering is much better
data.author: Osian Piercy

data.text: nice ride, I'm mostly road riding now because I'm old AF, but, I like a little bite I'm rolling stock in case I want to explore a side road.
data.author: Samuel Lea
Stefan la Grand

data.text: The mundial üëå
data.author: Stefan la Grand
